text: We see the fans rushing to the few platform ticket machin endless pennies being dropped and tickets torn out in the get onto the platform to see the boys. NORM has been waiting for the boys and he hurries them to their baggage, instruments and the drums are waiting, pil put into the guards' van. The boys turn and see the oncom girls pushing through the barriers and descending on them and shouts. They grab their instruments, RINGO makes for NORM plugs into a handy transformer and using their instr gun volley to stop the onrush of females, the boys blast number and start to sing. This stops the girls in their t settle down on whatever they can to listen to them playin As the boys are playing, we CUT BACK into the crowds. In see PAUL struggling and pulling to fight his way through join the other boys. He is dragging a very reluctant old him. The old man seems most disgruntled and we can see by how unwilling he is to be pulled and pushed forward throu girls. At last PAUL reaches the other boys. He sits the old man of cases and joins in the number to the squeals of deligh fans. The old man sits aloof and proud ignoring the whole JOHN, GEORGE and RINGO look enquiringly at PAUL who gives noncommittal shrug of the shoulders as if to say, "it's n and the number proceeds. SHOT of sudden horror on JOHN's face. PAUL follows his ey see the old man has doffed his cap and is busily collecti a disconcerted crowd. PAUL dives hastily into the crowd, suitable apologies extracts the old man and with a long s drags him back to the group. GEORGE and PAUL hold him fir finish the number, the old man standing there between the  the As the number finishes and the girls scream and shout wit guard blows his whistle. NORM and SHAKE grab the instrume drums, and with the rest piles the lot into the guards’ v head into their reserved compartment pursued by the fans moves off. They have successfully repelled all extra boar THE BOYS stand and wave to the fans until out of sight li girls running along to the end of the platform waving and

head_text.subj: INTERIOR RESERVED COMPARTMENT IN THE TRAIN

text: The boys relax, sitting down on one side of the compartme about to settle down and make themselves at home when fir nudges GEORGE who in turn nudges JOHN. Opposite them is s LITTLE OLD MAN. He is holding himself stiff, erect and ve The three boys look at him enquiringly but with an elabor looks away from them and out of the window. PAUL catches his eye and winks at the LITTLE OLD MAN. He PAUL, scowls at the other three then looks firmly out of again. The boys turn on PAUL crowding around him.
Eh ... pardon me for asking but who's that little old man?
What little old man?
(pointing) That little old man.
Oh, that one. That's me Grandfather.
That's not your Grandfather.
It is, y'know.
But your Grandfather lives in your house. I've seen him.
Oh, that's me other Grandfather, but this one's me Grandfather and all.
How d'you reckon that one out?
Well ... everyone's entitled to two, aren't they, and this is me other one.
(long suffering) Well we know that but what's he doing here?
Well, me mother thought the trip 'ud do him good.
How's that?
Oh ... he's nursing a broken heart. The lads all look intently at the GRANDFATHER.
Aah ... the poor old thing. He leans across to GRANDFATHER.
Eh, Mister... are you nursing a broken heart then? The GRANDFATHER nods soulfully glares at him, in a way th yes.
(whispering) You see, he was going to get married but she threw him over for a butcher.
A butcher?
Yeah, she was fickle.
Aye and fond of fresh meat and all.
(seriously) No ... it was his sweetbreads. She was dead kinky for sweetbreads. Anyroad, me mother thought it'ud give him a change of scenery, like.
Oh, I see. indicates  He inspects GRANDFATHER carefully.
(to PAUL) Eh, he's a nice old man, isn't he?
Oh yeah, he's very clean, y'know. They all agree with PAUL. JOHN has been examining GRANDFATHER. He now leans forward
(in an over-friendly voice) Hello, Grandfather!
Hello.
(delightedly) He can talk then?
(indignantly) Course he can talk. He's a human being, like. Isn't he?
(grinning) Well ... if he's your Grandfather, who knows? The lads all laugh.
And we're looking after him, are we?
I'll look after meself.
Aye, that's what I'm afraid of!
He's got you worried, then?
Him, he costs you a fortune in breach of promise cases. He's a villain and a right mixer as well.
(disbelieving) Gerron.
No, straight up.
The lad's given you the simple truth. I'm cursed wid irresistible charm, I'm too attractive to be let loose. At this moment, SHAKE, a tall man who works with the BOYS the door of the compartment.
You got on all right then?
Hi, Shake.
We're here. Norm'll be along in a mo' with the tickets. He sees GRANDFATHER.
Morning! (whispers) Who's that little old man?
It's Paul's grandfather.
Oh aye, but I thought ...
(cutting in) No, that's his other one.
That's all right then.
(displaying Grandfather) Clean though, isn't he?
Oh yes, he's clean all right. NORM the road manager appears behind SHAKE.
Morning, lads.
Morning ... Hi, Norm.

(checking them quickly) pulls open  Well, thank God you're all got here. Now, listen, I've had this marvellous idea ... now just for a change, let's all behave like ordinary responsible citizens. Let's not cause any trouble, pull any strokes or do anything I'm going to be sorry for, especially tomorrow at the television theatre, because ... He looks sharply at JOHN who is polishing his nails.
Are you listening to me, Lennon?
(off-hand) You're a swine, isn't he George?
(disinterested) Yeah ... a swine.
(just as indifferent) Thanks... He sees the GRANDFATHER.
Eh ...
... Who's that little old man?
Well, who is he?
He belongs to Paul.
(accepting the situation) Ah well, there you go. Look, I'm going down the diner for a cup of coffee, are you coming?
We'll follow you down. GRANDFATHER rises.
I want me coffee.
He can come with Shake and me if you like.
Well, look after him. I don't want to find you've lost him.
Don't be cheeky, I'll bind him to me with promises. Come on, Grandad. GRANDFATHER joins SHAKE and NORM.

(over Grandfather's head) He's very clean, isn't he? SHAKE and NORM collect GRANDFATHER and are in the process the compartment when a fat upper class city Englishman, J attempts to enter. There is a bit of confusion and they g with each other.

Make up your minds, will you! At last SHAKE, NORM and GRANDFATHER sort themselves out a enters with his case. The other three go to coffee. JOHNSON puts his case up on the luggage rack, then sits d movements are disgruntled ... he finally picks up his cop Financial Times and burying himself behind it, starts to moment he looks up, notices the compartment window is ope and without so much as a "by your leave" he closes it, gl BOYS and sits down again. The boys exchange looks as if to say ... “Hello, Saucy!!"
(politely) Do you mind if we have it opened?
(briefly) Yes, I do.
Yeah, but there are four of us, like, and we'd like it open, if it's all the same to you, that is.
(rudely) Well, it isn't. I travel on this train regularly twice a week, so I suppose I've some rights.

Aye, well, so have we. He disappears behind his paper before the BOYS can say an RINGO pulls a face at the raised paper and switches on h radio. A pop number is playing. JOHNSON puts down his paper firmly.
And we'll have that thing off as well, thank you.
But I... JOHNSON leans over and switches it off.
An elementary knowledge of the Railway Acts would tell you I'm perfectly within my rights. He smiles frostily.
Yeah, but we want to hear it and there's more of us than you. We're a community, like, a majority vote. Up the workers and all that stuff!
Then I suggest you take that damned thing into the corridor or some other part of the train where you obviously belong.
(leaning forward to him) Gie's a kiss!
Shurrup! Look, Mister, we've paid for our seats too, you know.
I travel on this train regularly, twice a week.
Knock it off, Paul, y' can't win with his sort. After all, it's his train, isn't it, Mister?
And don't you take that tone with me, young man!
But...
(accusingly) I fought the war for your sort.
Bet you're sorry you won!
I'll call the guard!

Aye ... but what? They don't take kindly to insults you know. Ah, come on, you lot. Let's get a cup of coffee and leave Toby the manger. The boys troop out of the door into the corridor. JOHNSON triumphantly. He is about to settle down to his paper whe tap on the corridor window. He looks up and we see presse window a collection of hideous Beatle faces.
Eh, Mister ... can we have our ball back! The man jumps to his feet.
The boys run away like a pack of school boys and disappea corner.
From the P.O.V. of the door leading to the restaurant car The boys come down the corridor in full flight, laughing happy idiots. GEORGE and PAUL pull open the sliding doors look inside.

From their P.0.V. we see the car is half empty and at a t centre SHAKE and NORM and GRANDFATHER are sitting. On the pile of photos of the boys. NORM and SHAKE are arguing. N very aggressive, much to SHAKE's discomfort.
Yeah, you want to watch it.
(unhappily) It's not my fault.
Well, you stick to that story, son.
I can't help it, I'm just taller than you.
(To NORM slyly) They always say that.
Yeah, well I got me eye on you.
I'm sorry Norm, but I can't help being taller than you.
Well, you don't have to rub me nose in it. I've a good mind to ... (he is about to thump SHAKE.)
(enjoying himself) If you're going to have a barney I'll hold your coats.
He started it.
No, I didn't you did...
Well, what happened?
The old fella wanted these pictures and Norm said he couldn't have ‘em, all I said was ‘aw go on, be big about it.'
And?
Your Grandfather pointed out Shake was always being taller than me just to spite me.
I knew it, he started it, I should have known.
Y'what?

You two have never had a quarrel in your life and in two minutes flat he's got you at it. He's a king mixer. Adam and Eve, meet the serpent. Anthony and Cleopatra, there's your asp. Divide and Conquer, that's this one's motto. He hates group unity so he gets everyone at it. The BOYS, i.e., JOHN, GEORGE and RINGO, look at each othe  PAUL.
Aye and we'll have to watch it and all.
I suggest you just give him the photos and have done with it.
You're right. Here you are, old devil. SHAKE and NORM leave. GRANDFATHER grins triumphantly and them, then with a sweet smile he turns to PAUL.
Would you ever sign this one for us, Pauly? PAUL does so automatically but in the middle of signing h suspicious. GRANDFATHER smiles at him charmingly so PAUL signing.
Come on let's get this coffee.

Before you go, I think it's only fair to warn you about me Grandson ... don't let our Paul have his own way all the time, 'cos if you do he won't respect you! JOHN, RINGO and GEORGE take this up straight away. They a be girls, RINGO jumps into PAUL's arms.
(coyly) Oh, Paul, you can't have your own way!!!
(invitingly, in a Marlene Dietrich voice) If I let you have your own way, you little rascal, will you respect me?
(choked) I'll murder you, Grandfather! JOHN waltzes PAUL down to an empty table and the lads sit
Eh, look at that talent. They all gaze across the aisle. From their P.O.V. we see attractive young girls, RITA and JEAN, having coffee.
Give 'em a pull.
Shall I?
Aye, but don't rush. None of your five bar gate jumps and over sort of stuff.
Now what's that supposed to mean?
(grinning) I don't really know, but it sounded distinguished, like, didn't it?
George Harrison, The Scouse of Distinction. We follow PAUL as he crosses over to the two girls. He pl on his head.

(in posh accent) Excuse me, but these young men I'm sitting with wondered if two of us could join you; I'd ask you meself only I'm shy. The two girls giggle together. JOHN and GEORGE are about to move over when GRANDFATHER s appears by their sides.
(sternly) I'm sorry, miss, but you mustn't fraternise with my prisoners.
Prisoners!!
Convicts in transit to Wormwood Scrubs. Typical old lags, the lot of ‘em.
Y'what!!!
Quiet, you lot, or I'll give you a touch of me truncheon. (He points at Ringo) That little one's the worst. If we don't keep him on tablets he has fits.
(protesting) Now look here!! GRANDFATHER grabs two lumps of sugar from the table and f into RINGO'S mouth.

Get out while you can, ladies, his time's coming round for one of his turns. The frightened girls scurry out of the restaurant car. Th in amazement and horror at GRANDFATHER. They are completely flabbergasted. GRANDFATHER smiles at them benignly.
SHAKE and NORM are seated. SHAKE is buried in a science f NORM looks at his watch, slightly worried.
He's been gone a long time.
(without looking up) Who?
Paul's grandfather.
Oh, I didn't notice, where'd he go?
Down the ... er ...
Oh, down the ... er ...?
Yeah, down the ... er ...
Well, give a couple of minutes ... He resumes reading. But NORM goes on worrying.
Grandfather is in full flight of conversation with a char lady, AUDREY, who is listening intently.
(proudly) Yes, I'm their manager, I discovered them.
Did you indeed, Mr. McCartney?
Now, Audrey, I told you, the name's John. We show biz people are a friendly lot.
Of course, John.

Yes, they were playing the queues outside the picture palaces of Liverpool. Scruffy young lads, lacking even the price of a jam roll. Orphans, every Paddy's son of ‘em. I saw their potential at once although I had me doubts about the little fella, a savage primitive, that Ringo, but it was him what gave in first. He picked up a brick and heaved it at me and I quelled him wid one fierce flash of me eyes. "Mister, can you spare us a copper?" he said. I was disarmed by the grubby little outstretched mauler ... So, I took them under me managerial banner.
The usual ten per cent?
Oh, not at all, I let them have twenty-five; sure aren't there four of them?
(her eyes lighting up) How fascinating. Do go on ... (pause) .+. John.
-+. Oh, I'm all heart, Ma'am, all heart ... Well, I let...
NORM and SHAKE meet with the BOYS as they are returning f
Eh, have you got Paul's grandfather?
Of course, he's concealed about me person.
No ... he's must have slipped off somewhere.  11.
(accusingly) Have you lost him?
Don't exaggerate.
You've lost him.
Put it this way, he's mislaid him.
You can't trust you with anything, Norm, if you've lost him, I'll cripple you.
He can't be far.
I hope he fell off.
(mildly) Don't be callous.
He doesn't like me, honest, I can tell ... It's ‘cos I'm little.
You've got an inferiority complex, you have.

Yeah, I know, that's why I took up the drums. It's me active compensatory factor. JOHN and PAUL run down the corridor. SHAKE and NORM turn and go in the opposite direction, GEORGE and RINGO follow other two boys.

PAUL and JOHN look into various compartments. CLOSE SHOT looking into compartments in the manner of Groucho Marx. compartments we see from RINGO'S P.O.V. the occupant, a g woman, TANIA, with a small lap dog. She is beautifully and most expensively dressed. She look RINGO. RINGO smiles at her and she smiles back. She then beckons her. He looks around to see if she means someone else. She nod RINGO looks back enquiringly then points at himself as i “Who, me?" TANIA smiles enthusiastically. GEORGE has been watching all this.
Are you going in?
No, she'll only reject me in the end and I'll be frustrated.
You never know, you might be lucky this time.
No, I know the psychological pattern and it plays hell with me drum skins. He blows the glamorous lady a kiss, then moves sadly on.
PAUL enters a compartment followed by JOHN. The TWO GIRLS JEAN, from the restaurant car are sitting there.
Excuse me but have you seen that little old man we were with? The girls jump up, surprised.
We've broken out, oh, the blessed freedom of it all! (he extends his hands as if handcuffed) Eh, have you got a nail file, these handcuffs are killing me. I was framed. I was innocent.
Will you stop it! Sorry to disturb you, miss... He starts to drag JOHN after him.
I was innocent. I was framed. I won't go back. JOHN is now by the door; he leers at the girls horribly.

I bet you can guess what I was in for. He cackles like a maniac before disappearing, the door cl  13. him. A waiter carrying a tray with champagne and glasses on it one of the compartments with the blinds down.
How about that one? He moves towards the compartment.
(to Ringo and George) Did you look in here?
No. I mean, it's probably a honeymoon couple or a company director or something.
Well, let's broaden our outlook. PAUL opens the door of the compartment.
From the BOYS' P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER and the elderly sipping champagne and nibbling caviar on toast.
(looking up) Congratulate me, boys, I'm engaged. PAUL enters and crosses over to him.
Oh no, you're not. You've gone too far this time ... and who's paying for all this?
It's all taken care of. It's down on our bill.
Oh, well that's all right. (realising) What?
Young man, kindly moderate your tone when you address my fiance.
I'm sorry, Missus, but the betrothal's off. (He grabs GRANDFATHER by the arm.) I'll refuse me consent, he's over-age! AUDREY grabs GRANDFATHER's other arm and pulls back.  14.
Leave him alone, after all he's done for you is this the way you repay him? A tug of war now starts between PAUL and AUDREY.
(pulling) Him? he's never done anything for anybody in his life.

(pulling) You dare to say that when even those ridiculous clothes you are wearing were bought when you forced him to sell out his gilt edged Indomitables!! JOHN and GEORGE jump on the seat egging PAUL and AUDREY o
Come on, Auntie, you're winning.
Get in there, Paul, she's weakening. RINGO attempts to interfere.
Look, Missus, this is all a misunderstanding, you see, he's ...
Keep away from me, you depraved lout, I know all about your terrible past.
Y'what? She hits RINGO with her handbag and continues struggling GRANDFATHER. RINGO grabs her handbag to stop her hitting

He's given me a bad character, blackguarding me name to all and sundry. He's got to be stopped. It's not fair. RINGO pushes out into the corridor, forgetting that he is woman's handbag. A voice shouts off from outside.
That's one of them ... stop thief!

From Ringo's P.O.V. we see down to the right the city ma approaching with a GUARD. RINGO turns the other way to th he is joined by [the] three other boys. From their P.O.V. do corridor we see the two girls, autograph books in hand, f ten girls from the same school. Both groups are closing in on the BOYS. There's no escape
(looking down at the handbag in his hand) Oh Mother! !

Very dark, and behind bars we see GRANDFATHER. He is sitt up on a wooden box tea chest and looks pretty miserable. towards the CAMERA; in the foreground of the SHOT we see standing. In the background an impassive GUARD is reading a paper w throughout the scene.
(bitterly) And to think me own grandson would have let them put me behind bars!

Don't dramatise. The CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see GRANDFATHER in the lugga compartment of the guards' van. In with him are a crate of chickens a chickens peck at him; GRANDFATHER moves listlessly away.
Let's face it, you're lucky to be here. If they'd have had their way you'd have been dropped off at Stafford already. GRANDFATHER proudly turns away from PAUL who dodges round still see his face.
Well, you've got to admit you've upset a lot of people. At least I can keep my eye on you while you're stuck in here. GRANDFATHER turns away again.

All right, how about Ringo? I mean ... he's very upset, you know ... and as far as your girlfriend, little Audrey's concerned, she's  finished with men for the rest of her natural, and another thing ...
A harmless bit of fun, aah, none of you have any sense of humour left these days.
Oh, it's all right for you but those two girls were scared to death! Honest, Grandad, why? I mean, why do you do these things?
(cutting in) You're left-handed, aren't you, Paul?
Yeah ... so what?
Why do you always use your left hand?
Well, don't be daft, I've got to.
And I take a left-handed view of life, I've got to. PAUL grins. After a moment of looking at him, PAUL opens the luggage compartment and joins GRANDFATHER on a box.
Shove up! GRANDFATHER produces a penny.
Odds or evens? PAUL sighs.
Odds. GRANDFATHER flips the coin. The guards' van door opens and JOHN, GEORGE and RINGO com them are the girls, RITA and JEAN.
(as he sees PAUL behind the bars) Don't worry, son, we'll get you the best lawyer trading stamps can buy.
Oh, it's a laugh a line with Lennon.  16. nearer 17. 18. (to Ringo) Anyroad up ... It's all your fault.
Me? Why?
Bag-snatcher.
That's right; convict without trial ... Habeas corpus.
(casually) Every morning. JOHN has been looking around the guards' van.

Gaw, it's depressing in here, isn't it? Funny... (he pats the dog) ‘cos they usually reckon dogs more than people in England, don't they? You'd expect something a little more palatial. (he shudders) Come on. Let's have a little action. Let's do something, then.
Like what?

Well, I've got me gob stopper. (he produces his mouth organ.) Look, a genuine Stradivarius, hand tooled at Dagenham. And to RINGO's beat on a tea chest they are off, PAUL and improvising other sounds, much to the GIRLS' delight. Dur number, GRANDFATHER quietly lets the latch off the chicke chickens begin to wander through the scene.

head_text.subj: EXTERIOR TRAIN IN MOTION FROM ABOVE, (NIGHT)

text: While the number is progressing, the train is getting nea to London.
SHOTS of the station full of GIRLS waiting for the BOYS.
By the time the number finishes the train pulls up with a  19. 20. that sends them all sprawling, BOYS and GIRLS. NORM enters the guards' van.
Don't move, any of you. They've gone potty out there. The whole place is surging with girls.
Please, can I have one to surge with?
No.
Ah, go on, you swine.

No, you can't. Look, as soon as I tell you, run through this door here and into the big car that's waiting. He points and we see a big car parked across the road. The BOYS prepare to depart, lining up with GRANDFATHER at
Just as they are ready to go, a line of taxis draws up pa train and now separates them from the big car waiting for
Oh no! GRANDFATHER pushes past the BOYS, holding his coat closed

All right, lads, follow me. And before NORM can stop him, he darts out of the door, P The fans further down the platform see PAUL and charge fo panic NORM and the others follow, JOHN just having time t the girls.
Vive l'amour! NORM drags him away.

The BOYS manage to follow GRANDFATHER by leaping onto a m luggage carrier, GEORGE driving and the other three posin tableau on the back. GRANDFATHER has arrived at a taxi do it open and runs through, opening the other door, thus ma  21. 22. off. hotel 23. is room. the bridge to the car. The BOYS follow and manage to make it to the big car safe towards grandfather's taxi. The FANS have followed the BO streams of GIRLS piling through all the taxis one of whic JOHNSON the city man, opening and shutting the doors to g much to the indignation of the TAXI DRIVERS.
NORM is sitting in front with the driver, FRANK. The four GRANDFATHER are squashed together in the back.
(to the driver) Go like the clappers, son!
(smoothly) That was my entire intention, sir.
The car moves off surrounded by the FANS; from a height w converge on the car but it moves forcefully out of the st It moves into the traffic in the main road and the journe begins.

There is a reception room and off it lead rooms that are bedrooms, bathroom, etc. JOHN is lying sprawled out on a listening to a transistor radio, demolishing a basket of sitting at an upright piano and GRANDFATHER is mooching a One of the doors opens and GEORGE enters followed by RING BOYS are wearing coats.
I don't snore.
You do - repeatedly.
(to John) Do I snore?
(eating a banana) You're a window rattler, son.
Well, that's just your opinion. Do I snore, Paul?
(stopping playing) With a trombone hooter like yours it'd be unnatural if you didn't.
Don't mock the afflicted, Pauly.
Oh for Pete's sake, It's only a joke.

Well, it may be a joke, but it's his nose. He can't help having a horrible great nose, it's the only one he's got. And his poor little head's trembling under the weight of it. NORM enters with three piles of fan mail and places them JOHN on a table. RINGO is almost in tears, examining his mirror.
Paul, John, George - get at it.
Hello the income tax have caught up with us at last. PAUL and GEORGE gather round the low table. RINGO is left
None for me, then?
Sorry. John hands RINGO a single envelope.
That'll keep you busy.
It's your nose, y'see. Fans are funny that way. Take a dislike to things. They'll pick on a nose...
You go and pick on your own. SHAKE enters with a stack of mail about three times large the others put together.
Is that yours?
For Ringo. He dumps it in Ringo's arms who staggers into an armchair send him up.
That must have cost you a fortune in stamps, Ringo.
He comes from a large family.
(dumping the letters) Well. RINGO opens his letter and reads it. It contains a large card.
Eh, what's Boyd's Club? The lads gather round him and PAUL takes the card from hi

“The Management of Boyd's takes pleasure in requesting the company of Mr. Richard Starkey that's you, in their recently refinished gaming rooms. Chemin de Fer. Baccarat, Roulette, and Champagne Buffet." Blimey!
(surprised) And they want me?
Oh, it's got round that you're a heavy punter
(snatching the card Well you're not going.
Ah.
(taking card from Norm) Quite right, invites to gambling dens full of easy money and fast women, chicken sandwiches and cornets of caviar, disgusting! He pockets the card himself.
That's mine.
Have done, and you lot get your pens out.
Why?
It's homework time for all you college puddings. I want this lot (he indicates the fan letters all answered tonight. The BOYS all protest.
I'll brook no denial!
It's all right for you, you couldn't get a pen in your foot, you swine.
Come on, Shake, we'll leave ‘em to their penmanship. He goes followed by SHAKE. There is a pause and JOHN deliberately rises slowly and c coat. He puts it on and walks to the door.
While the swine's away the piglets can play. Well, come on, what are we waiting for? With a whoop PAUL, GEORGE and RINGO collect their coats a the door.
What about all these letters?
Read ‘em! They disappear. After a moment GRANDFATHER takes out Ring

And a free champagne buffet. He grins to himself. At this moment a WAITER enters with clad in tails and GRANDFATHER eyes them longingly, measur the while alongside the startled waiter. He leaves us wit our minds what he wants, i.e., the waiter's suit

The club is the latest in modern decor and full of teenag enjoying themselves. The CAMERA wanders around the club t finally picks out JOHN, PAUL, GEORGE and RINGO all crowded around table. The music is blaring away from a juke box and the dancers. They are recognised and given smiles and nods of encouragement by all the other customers. During this scene we

The whole atmosphere is of quiet elegance and loud wealth baccarat table the rich, bored customers sit barely movin muscle as they languidly murmur "suivez" and "banco" to t he operates the shoe. The manager of the club is beaming satisfaction as he surveys his customers. One of these cu clad in evening dress and he has his back to us. The rest players (male) are in suits. By each of them is standing with a bored sophisticated face that looks as if it has b on. From the REVERSE of the LAST SHOT we now see the soli dress player is GRANDFATHER. He looks around him and wipe look of enjoyment and elaborately out-bores everyone in the ro
Alors, M'sieur?
(nonchalant) Souflée. He turns to the buxom BLONDE, who is dripping over him.
I bet you're a great swimmer. My turn? Bingo!
Pas "Bingo," M'sieur... Banco.
(taking) I'll take the little darlings anyway. He takes up the cards and can't understand that they are
Two and one is three, carry one is four. The buxom BLONDE leans over him.
Lay them down.
(disturbed by his eyeline) Eh?
Lay them down.
We'd be thrown out.
Your cards... lay them down... face up. He does so.
Huit a la pointe... et sept. (He pushes chips and box to Grandfather.)
You had a lovely little pair, y'see.
I dia? CROUPIER taps impatiently on box (shoe).
They're yours.
They are?

No!
Oh, he's gone to my club, has he?
(turning on Ringo) Yeah, It's all your fault, getting invites to gambling clubs. He's probably in the middle of an orgy by now.
Well, what are we waiting for?
Aye, come on, honest, that grandfather of yours is worse than any of you lot.
GRANDFATHER is drinking champagne in locked arms with BLO
Encore de champagne, Monsieur?

Play is about to resume, m'lord.

(handing him a chip) Lead me to it, I've a winning itch that only success can pacify. He takes his place at the table. The MANAGER watches for moves away from the table towards the club reception desk
JOHN, PAUL, GEORGE, RINGO, NORM and SHAKE are trying to g
I'm sorry sir, members and invited guests only.
I've got to get in. It's urgent and important. I've had an invite. Take me to your leader.
Shurrup. The BOYS do and meanwhile the MANAGER has walked into SHO recognises the BOYS and welcomes them with false enthusia start to enter the main room.
All we want to know is have you got a little old man in there?
(pleasantly) Do you mean Lord McCartney?
He's at it again. Look, I'm his grandfather.  I mean...
(standing next to Grandfather) Oh, it must be the dolly floor show.
Stay where you are everybody this is a raid and we want him.

Who are these ruffians?... I've never seen them before in my life! ... (etc.) They grab the protesting GRANDFATHER and drag him into th area. He keeps trying to return to BLONDE and table. GEOR each take an end of the velvet cord hanging between the t stanchions. They exchange ends and re-hook it, thus encircling GRANDF entrance desk. They then go to settle up.
(with false charm) Before you go, gentlemen, there's the small matter of the bill. He snaps his fingers and a waiter hands him the bill.
(taking it) I'll settle that. He glances at it.
A hundred and eighty pounds!
(icily) I beg your pardon, guineas. At that moment a WAITER appears with a tray full of pound
Your winnings, my lord, one hundred and ninety pounds. The MANAGER tears up the bill and takes the money.
How about me change?
Cloak room charge. He hands GRANDFATHER his old mackintosh.
(brightly) Ah well, easy come, easy go. The others glower at him.
Well.

text: The BOYS have settled down.
Should I say it?
Follow your impulse.
It'll only get you into trouble.
(to RINGO) Aah, shurrup, misery! JOHN slouches forward.

Well, that's the wrong line for a start.
Sorry? (meaning: "I beg your pardon.")
Oh, don't pay any attention to him, he was just fulfilling a lifelong ambition.
I see.
Yeah, you know, "O.K. Buster, follow that car, there's a sawbuck in it for you if you get real close!"  34. them. 35.

Oh, yes, now I'm with you. [he changes his accent] But, gee, Mister, I've got my license to think of ... we're doing a hundred now ... The car is stopped in traffic behind a bus. JOHN gets out walks to the front. JOHN leans in window delightedly, he wallet.
Ever seen one of these before?
Ah ... a shamus, eh?
I see you go to the night court.
I've made the scene.
Well, remember, its Leathery Magee up ahead in that convertible, so cover me in the stake-out.
I don't think that bit's right.
What do you expect from an ad lib ... Raymond Chandler?

As the big car overtakes a Company Director's Rolls. JOHN window and the boys let out an imaginary hail of bullets Executive in the back. He reacts violently and starts to As he does so, he presses the button of his window, so th only part of it. But what we do is unpleasant. He immedia the button and the window rises. RINGO and PAUL jump out of the car. RINGO takes two drums coat pocket and, using them as banderillas, inserts them into the radiator grill (V.0. "Ole" from the BOYS). Will you all stop it, you're like a gang of  36. 37. 38. school kids. I knew this was going to happen one day.
(as Ringo and Paul climb in) Well, you shouldn't have had bacon for your breakfast, you cannibal.
(to Norm) We're nearly there, sir.
Eh ... don't call him sir, he's got enough delusions of power as it is. CLOSE SHOT of a long suffering NORM.
And I was happy in the bakery. I'll never know why I left.

text: Which has been converted to the T.V. studios.
There are a few groups of GIRL FANS standing outside the theatre, but against the kerb of the pavement is a night- canvas hut and brazier. The car approaches.

Get ready John, open the door and as it draws up, out you go and straight in. JOHN nods and opens the door. As the BOYS enter, two P.R.O. men in dark suits, stiff wh and old school ties step forward and smile menacingly.
(menacingly) Press conference, they're waiting for you.
(jovially) Give us a couple of shakes to get our breath.  39. and of is
(more menacingly) They're waiting now! And without more ado they grab an arm each and march the NORM towards the stairs that lead to the dress circle.
Eh this lot means it. They're even taking hostages. The BOYS, SHAKE and GRANDFATHER rush after the rapidly di NORM, who by now is half way up the stairs.

text: It is empty except for two barmaids poised ready to serve behind trestle tables full of drinks and sandwiches. The MEN enter with NORM and close behind them follow GRANDFAT the boys. The group arrives at the centre of the lounge a to look about and see the food but before they can get to directions NEWSPAPERMEN and PHOTOGRAPHERS converge upon t Now begins an elaborate tug-of-war between various PHOTOG their flash attachments and REPORTERS to capture a Beatle midst of this running battle a man with a portable record to interview them. Together and singly the BOYS are pushe room and while this goes on a hard core of NEWSPAPERMEN a devouring sandwiches and pouring themselves drinks, to th the BARMAIDS. Every time one of the BOYS attempts to get a sandwich or either too late, the plate is empty, or they are intercep single and constant thing we see in the scene is the push pulling, heavy impersonal handling, the boys are just thi placed like still life in one advantageous position after During the scene these individual exchanges take place:
What's your philosophy of life?
I'm torn between Zen and I'm all right, Jack.
Has success changed your life?
Yes.
Do you like playing the guitar?  out 40. put 41.
Next to kissing girls it's favourites. PAUL is surrounded by newspapermen.
No, actually, we're just good friends. HIGH SHOT of the press reception and we see the BOYS ease until they get to the curtained entrance to the dress cir completely unnoticed, they slip through.
The BOYS come up the stairs into the Dress Circle proper. and SHAKE are sitting there having a picnic of beer and s
(ironically) Anything to spare?
We've just finished, Pauly. Hey George, write us your John Henry on this picture.
Sure. (He does so).

Ah well. Eh, look! He points, and from PAUL'S P.O.V. we see on stage, the se the show, scenery and lights, cameras and sound equipment into position by a small army of studio staff. DANCERS an milling about as well.
Let's go and muck in.
Aye, before anyone stops us. They exit to rows of the dress circle and go through the the narrow stairs to the stalls and on to the stage that extended right into the stalls, which are partly covered
Everyone is so busy that they hardly notice the BOYS, who and examine the studio equipment. A load of three drum se brought on stage and a voice shouts out:
Here, what about these electric guitars?
Where are they?
Back here, mate.

(going towards the voice) I'm coming. RINGO is busy setting up his drums, and men are setting u sets. He drops a stick and the FLOOR MANAGER retrieves it to tap the drum. The FLOOR MANAGER is a languid young man
Leave them drums alone.
Oh, surely one can have a tiny touch.
If you so much as breathe heavy on them, I'm out on strike.
Aren't you being rather arbitrary?
That's right retreat behind a smoke screen of bourgeois cliches. I don't go round messing about with your ear-phones, do 1?
Spoil sport!
Well! RINGO fusses like a mother hen clucking over his drums. T MANAGER is furious.
He's very touchy about those his drums, they loom large in his legend. RINGO gives his drums a defiant crash and JOHN and PAUL s they are up to and hurry over.
What's up?
(pointing) He's sulking again.

are 42. the I'll show him. He picks up a set of drum sticks and bashes back at RINGO more complicated drum roll. GEORGE now joins in and to PA encouragement a drum duel starts completely naturally and During this encounter the work proceeds around them and t brought on and SHAKE sets them to working order. PAUL fir and GEORGE take up their own instruments and out of the d emerges one of their numbers.
As the number finishes a baldheaded man (he is the T.V. d storms down the ramp that leads from the control box unde circle.

(with over-exaggerated calm) All right I'm sorry and let's hear no more about it. If that's your opinion, you're probably right. Look, if you think I'm unsuitable let's have it out in the open, I can't stand these back-stage politics. By the end of this speech he is standing in front of JOHN scene in his stride.
Aren't you tending to black and white this whole situation?
Well, quite honestly I wasn't expecting "a musical arranger" who would question my ability ... picture-wise.
(to the others) I could listen to him for hours.
Heave to, what's all this about a musical arranger?
Mr. McCartney Senior! The BOYS have a giggle at the very idea and at this momen appears from behind the DIRECTOR.
Hey Pauly, they're trying to fob you off wid this musical charlatan but I've given him the test.  away
(bravely) I'm quite happy to be replaced.
(indicating the director) He's a typical buck-passer.
I won an award.
A likely story.
It's on the wall in my office. At this moment NORM comes on the stage, confident, cigar serene.
Hello our lot, everyone happy? The BOYS, the DIRECTOR, FLOOR MANAGER and GRANDFATHER tur stare silently.
All right, all right. If you don't need this lot, I'll lock 'em up in the dressing room till you do.
Please do, I'll not need them for fifteen minutes. Thank you. He glares at GRANDFATHER who glares right back. The DIREC with the FLOOR MANAGER pacifying him.
Give me a bottle of milk and a packet of Oblivion. Oh, it's a plot, I see it now, it's all a plot. They go left towards the back-stage.
(producing key) Now, come on, I've got the key. He leads the lads off right. RINGO is last as he is putti sticks down safely. NORM and the BOYS turn on him.
Let's have you.  sound 43.
Come on speedy!
Ringo!

Wake up! RINGO glares at them and follows quickly. As the BOYS mov NORM, they pass the next act waiting for rehearsal. It is man in full-tail suit meticulously adjusting his cuff-lin is a free-standing sign reading "Leslie Jackson and his t disappearing doves." The BOYS pass him and go through the GRANDFATHER stops and looks at the performer with respect

I can't tell you how much I've enjoyed your act. He slaps the man on the back with happy camaraderie. Ther of a dove, a few feathers fall out of the sleeve of the m he and GRANDFATHER look down at the floor. The man glares GRANDFATHER, takes out a pen from his pocket, crosses out sign, and writes "9" in its place, puts the pen back in h starts towards the centre stage putting on a false perfor
he does.

The BOYS move down the narrow stairs, and out of the grou dressing rooms stream a steady flow of costumed actors an They engulf the lads and force them against the wall -- t all making for the stage door. As the actors push past th the boys' excited faces, their mouths watering for the co touches the costume on one actor.
(to actor) Gear costume!
(eyeing him) Swap?

Right, first floor and no messing about. NORM, leading the way, goes up the stairs but as they tur corner they are confronted by a group of girls, a game of starts, "after you," "No, after you." NORM who is ahead o looks down on them in disgust.
looking 45. shows. step out Lennon, leave them girls alone or I'll report you. The BOYS let the GIRLS pass and resume the journey, alway by people.
RINGO'S attention is caught by a door. He crosses and ope out to a fire escape. The others join him and the four bo through the door and onto the fire escape.

From the BOYS' P.O.V. we see down below into the property the theatre. It is a long narrow yard full of old coaches and all the general debris of hundreds of sets from past Through the piles of heaped high junk there are a couple alleyways. The BOYS scamper down the fire escape. When they reach the bottom of the alleyways, there is a l They open it and look through. From their P.0.V. we see a large green field quite empty. through the doorway into the field. We now see from a HEL the four BOYS standing together surrounded by space. It is the first time they have been alone and unconfined They look at each other and grin ... then first GEORGE an a whoop and run towards the centre of the field, after a and RINGO follow them. The BOYS pick up some loose straw under JOHN'S cap and sleeves, turning him into a scarecro The four BOYS dash about madly calling out to one another generally them. horsing around. Out of this emerges an imaginary game of although there is no ball the game is fast and furious. A moments the long shadow of a man falls across the grass.

(off) I suppose you know this is private property. The boys freeze. From their P.0.V. we see a big burly middle-aged man glow The boys exchange rueful glances and, under the big man's back towards the gateway they came in by. JOHN is the las through. He turns to the man.  46. 47. someone 48. each leading 48a.
Sorry if we hurt your field, Mister.
