text: Under the stage the usual set of wooden columns that supp with lots of furniture and a single light is on; it is pl orchestra's entrance to the orchestra pit. GRANDFATHER co stairs and winds his way through the columns until he fin safe little cubby hole and settles himself under the ligh the signed photos of the BOYS in front of him and, adjust fashioned pair of glasses, ball-point pen in hand begins BOYS' signatures on to the fresh photos, tutting at his f chuckling at his successes. After a moment, there is a so coming down the stairs. GRANDFATHER darts into a dark pat sight. The menacing shadows appear on the stairway. NORM (voice off) There's no one here. SHAKE (voice off) This is the only way they could have gone. We now see GRANDFATHER holding himself stiffly in, he is of raised platform and he fidgets and in doing so he knoc some sort. Slowly GRANDFATHER ascends out of shot with a grows bigger above him.

A rehearsal of the toast scene from a Strauss Operetta. T stage is full of SINGERS, glasses in hand they are singin other but in true opera tradition they are addressing out audience. Slowly in-between the leading man and leading w about to embrace, a stage trap opens and a blinking, surp GRANDFATHER appears. Here we INTERCUT to the T.V. Control amazed reaction shots of the DIRECTOR and control room CR Back now on the stage the toast song reaches its climax a man and woman rush into each other's arms, GRANDFATHER sa between them.

head_text.subj: INTERIOR CORRIDOR AS BOYS PASS THRU ON WAY TO DRESSING RO

text: JOHN is behind them. JOHN, BOYS and MILLIE are walking to  other.
(as all pass) Hello.
(stopping... the boys carry on past, not noticing her) Hello.
Oh, wait a minute, don't tell me you're ...
No, not me.
(insistently) Oh you are, I know you are.
No, I'm not.
You are.
I'm not, no.
Well, you look like him.
Oh do I? You're the first one who ever said that.
Oh you do, look. JOHN looks at himself in the mirror. JOHN examines himself in the mirror carefully.
My eyes are lighter.
(agreeing) Oh yes.
And my nose...
Well, yes your nose is. Very.
Is it?
I would have said so.
Aye, but you know him well.
(indignantly) No I don't, he's only a casual acquaintance.
(knowingly) That's what you tell me.
(suspiciously) What have you heard?
(blandly) It's all over the place, everyone knows.
Is it? Is it really?
Mind you, I stood up for you, I mean I wouldn't have it.
I knew I could rely on you.
(modestly) Thanks. MILLIE touches his arm then walks away. After a moment sh
You don't look like him at all. JOHN winks at her and she winks back.
NORM and SHAKE enter the room. The BOYS' TAILOR is there the BOYS.
Oh they've probably gone to the canteen, cup of tea, like.
That's too easy for Lennon. He crosses to door leading to fire escape.
(dramatically) He's out there somewhere, causing trouble just to upset me.
You're imagining it. You're letting things prey on your mind.
Oh no... this is a battle of nerves between John and me.
But John hasn't got any.
What?
Nerves.
I know, that's the trouble. He puffs nervously at his cigarette.
Oh, I've toyed with the idea of a ball and chain but he'd only rattle them at me... and in public and all. Sometimes I think he enjoys seeing me suffer. He hears something.
Get behind that door, they're coming. Someone's coming. Quick, hide! The two men hide behind the door. The boys enter the room last he shuts the door and faces SHAKE and NORM.
What are you doing there?
Hiding.
I think you're soft or something.
We weren't hiding. as JOHN is
Now?
Now. We were trying to catch you redhanded. I thought I told you lot to stay here?
Well ...
When I tell you to stay put, stay put.
(down on his knees) Don't cane me, sir, I was led astray.
Oh shurrup and come on John. They're waiting for you in the studio.
Oh dear, I feel like doing a bit of work.
Good lad, Ringo.
Oh, listen to teacher's pet.
You crawler.
He's betrayed the class.
Oh, leave off!!!
Temper! Temper!
Well ... CLOSE-UP on NORM's long suffering face.

Will you all get a move on! They're waiting for you! By this time the TAILOR has his tape stretched between hi measure GEORGE's shoulders. But since GEORGE has moved aw measuring space. JOHN takes up his scissors and cuts the
towards still
I now declare this bridge open. The BOYS run out the door.

Five beautiful MODELS are standing about in costume. One loose wool sweater which is almost completed. There is th juggling act's music off and a few of the girls are looki the centre stage. At the edge of frame is a collapsible t with green baize. On it are three spaced white plates. From the door off stage, above which is a sign "To Cantee Production Offices", GRANDFATHER enters eating a plate of toast. The knitting GIRL sees him and, in mime, asks him so that she can measure the sweater against him. GRANDFAT help, puts his plate of food on the green table between p three. He goes to be measured with the sweater. From the onstage area, a juggler's ASSISTANT (pretty girl backs up and with the usual theatrical flourishes picks u looking, plate number ONE and throws it off screen toward stage. There is a drum roll from orchestra. She then thro number TWO. We CUT on stage to the JUGGLER now balancing spinning plates on two poles, one in each hand. He has an his mouth and nods to his ASSISTANT, asking for the THIRD We CUT BACK to the ASSISTANT who, still not looking, thro which is GRANDFATHER's. There is the sound of an orchestr stopping and all the hangers-on in the scene look off int We hear the DIRECTOR's voice.
All right, hold it, hold it... O.K. John, wipe him down and we'll carry on with the next act. We

centre stage. The JUGGLER is as before but the spaghetti his head, having slipped off the third plate. The FLOOR MANAGER is bustling around, trying to help. We CUT BACK to back-stage. GRANDFATHER has finished being goes to the green table where he put his plate down. He p only remaining plate, looks at it, wondering where his fo shrugs and heads back towards the exit door as we hear th VOICE.
mutter CLOSE-UP on the distraught DIRECTOR.
Where are they? I said, where are they? Where are they?
(placating) They're coming, I promise you.

(fiercely) Now look, if they're not here on this floor in thirty seconds there's going to be trouble ... understand me ... trouble!!! Two STAGE HANDS are walking disinterestedly past, they lo DIRECTOR. lst STAGE HAND What's he on about, Taff?
Well ... he's being the director. Of course, he lives in a world of his own, mind. At this moment the boys, NORM, SHAKE and GRANDFATHER appe grab their instruments and prepare to play.
(to the director) Standing about, eh? Some people have it dead easy, don't they? The director is about to blow his top but manages to hold to the heavens.
(to himself) Of course, once you're over thirty, you're finished. It's a young man's medium and I just can't take the pace.
Are you as young as that, then?
Shurrup!
Isn't it always the way? Picking on us little fellas.
(to Shake) Shove the gentleman jockey in the make-up room  52. or something and keep your eye on him, will you?
I'm an electrician, not a wet nurse, y'know.
(threateningly) I'll set John on you!

(hastily) Oh, anything you say, Paul. He leads GRANDFATHER away. The BOYS are placed in position, instruments ready. The b near them. There is a mike hovering just over JOHN'S head attacking it. DIRECTOR'S VOICE (over Tannoy Run through the number and try not to jiggle out of your positions. The BOYS start the number, as the stage hands adjust thei When they've finished, they stand about spare.
The room is crowded with the usual personnel, P.A., elecs etc.... make-up supervisor and wardrobe mistress.
That was more or less all right for me. I'll give them one more run through then leave them alone until the dress ... (to make-up woman) Oh how about make-up?
Not really, they don't need it any. We'll just powder them off for shine.
Good. Norm, get them along to make-up will you?
(rising) Sure.
(looking into the monitor) And hurry, they're not looking too happy. From the director's P.0.V. we see into the monitor. The b around RINGO. We cut through the monitor into the same po studio.  (53.
(to Ringo) What's the matter with you? You were bashing away like a madman.
(briefly) You were twanging too loud.
How'd you like a dirty great drum roll giving you a clout right in the middle of your solo?
You're getting out of hand. I don't know what's come over you today.
That's right. It's always me, isn't it?
Since you ask, yes. (he laughs) Aah, come on, Ring, we love you. He puts his arm around Ringo's shoulder.
Well!
He'll get over it. NORM appears down the ramp speaking as he approaches.
All right, our lot, make-up.]

A smallish room with a line of chairs facing a wall mirro table. Each place is clearly marked and above each mirror name: Betty, Angela, Deirdre, Jenny. SHAKE and GRANDFATHER are sitting in splendid isolation. staring each other out.
You blinked!
I never did, you did. The BOYS enter.  boys
Hello, he's not talking to me. He's having a sulk.
Well, it must be catching. He's given it to the champ here. He indicates RINGO who ignores him.
Stop picking on him.
I don't need you to defend me, y'know, Norm.
Leave him alone, he's got swine fever.

Sit down, the lot of you. At this moment several actors come into the room. They ar in the uniform of officers in Wellington's army. Together they sit down, Beatles and soldiers all mixed up. Now a group of several pretty make-up girls make an entra boys herald their arrival with a chorus of “aye aye's" an whistles. JOHN meanwhile has helped himself to a big bear other lads are generally messing about with assorted make
Oh, this is impossible! We'll never get you all done in time.
Well, you'll just have to do us first... It makes no difference to them whether they're made up or not. (sees John with beard) And who's me, then?
(charmingly) My name's Betty... (pointing to the name on the mirror) Do you want a punch up your frogged tunic? NORM fights his way to JOHN.

Now listen, John, behave yourself or I'll murder you and, Shake, take that wig off, it suits you.  girls, SHAKE has a long blond girl's wig on. With the assistance NORM gets the boys seated into the chairs nearest the doo reason RINGO now has a Guardsman's busby wedged down almo eyes and is sitting with it under a hair drier, reading a "Queen" Magazine.
(to Ringo) What do you think are you're up to?
Someone put it on me.
Excuses, that's all we get and you know you fancy yourself in the Coldstreams. The GIRLS now move in and put make up bibs on the BOYS an powder them off.
You won't interfere with the basic rugged concept of my personality, will you, girl?
Eh, don't take out me lines.
Yeah, they give him that "Je ne sais quoi" rakish air. The lads laugh with pleasure. RINGO decides to try a little joke.
(indicating the busby he is still wearing) Short back and sides, please. The other look at him with mock disgust.
Behave...
Foreign devil ...
Control yourself... GRANDFATHER has been watching the powdering process.
In my considered opinion you're a bunch of sissies.  JOHN grabs a powder puff from his girl.
You know you're only jealous! And dabs the old man liberally with the powder much to GR annoyance.
Leave him alone, Lennon, or I'll tell them all the truth about you.
You wouldn't!
I would though. NORM goes out.
What's he know?
Nothing, he's trying to brainwash me and give me personality doubts ... oh, he's a swine but a clever swine, mind.

(impatiently) Lookit, I thought I was supposed to be getting a change of scenery and so far I've seen a train and a room, a car and a room and a room and a room. Well, that's maybe all right for a bunch of powdered gee-gaws like you lot but I'm feeling decidedly strait-jacketed. This is no life for a free-booting agent of my stamp. I'm a frustrated man and that class of McCartney is a dangerous McCartney.
(admiringly) What a clean old man.
(touchingly) You're too young for a fella of my cosmopolitan tastes, so don't press your luck.
He's sex-obsessed, the older generation are leading this country to galloping ruin. NORM returns leaving the door open, the boys hear the sou coming from the studio.  55. on 56.
They're nearly ready for you. They're just finishing the band call.
(jumping from his seat) Gear! Come on, girls, let's have a bit of a dance.
I don't think its allowed.

Well ... it wouldn't be any fun if it was! The BOYS drag the make-up GIRLS out of the room and into The GIRLS are still trying to finish making the BOYS up. As the BOYS and MAKE-UP GIRLS dance past, we see one of t singers combing his long hair straight back. Two STAGE HA wind machine past him and his hair is blown straight forw Beatle cut.
(passing him) Never. During dance, GEORGE takes off wig and places it on dummy identical hair underneath.

The work is still going on and the music is up full blast enter and with the GIRLS [and] they start a wild dance, h zulu, blue beat, the lot. LIONEL and DANCERS are doing th one side of the stage ... it becomes a challenge dance be groups. JOHN swings his GIRL onto the motorized CAMERA, W and starts to track through the GROUP. GEORGE is on anoth

The whole control room crew are watching the dance on all monitors. him, it The DIRECTOR is about to stop the boys but his GIRL P.A. with a shrug he lets the dance go on. We now cut between the dancers on the monitors and the bo dancing down on the studio floor. When the recorded music grab their instruments and go into a number. So we can watch every aspect of their work and with so ma gives the impression that there are many more boys than j When the number finally ends we are back in the studio o
Thank you gentlemen, you can break now while we push on with the show. The boys acknowledge this with a quaver of guitar chords roll. NORM is on them at once.
That was great, you've got about an hour but don't leave the theatre. JOHN grabs the arm of a sexy girl dancer.
She's going to show me her stamp collection.
(grabs a showgirl) So's mine.
John, I'm talking to you. This final run through is important. Understand? Important.
(like a pig) Oink! Oink! They dash off with the two beauties. GRANDFATHER is hovering in the background with SHAKE.
I want me cup of tea.
Shake.
I'm adjusting the decibels on the inbalance.
Clever. (he turns) George. But GEORGE is disappearing out of the door. NORM turns to RINGO.
He comes Look after him.
But...
Do I have to raise me voice?
(choked) Oh, all right. Come here, Grandad. And the two of them walk off, Ringo leading.

A man, whose act is playing tunes by hitting himself on t swallowing a handful of aspirin tablets. He starts rehear which consists of throwing his head back and slapping his to him, a JUGGLER is practising with four table tennis ba GRANDFATHER passes him and bumps his arm slightly. Only 3 down. There is the sound of coughing off. We
THE HEAD-PLAYER being patted on the back. The ball drops mouth and bounces slowly on the studio floor.

The canteen is about half full of actors many of which ar Nazi soldiers, with mock blood bandages and arm bands. Al sprinkling of T.V. people. At a table sits GRANDFATHER an is deeply engrossed in a book and GRANDFATHER has a near tea in front of him. The old man is bored and looks about then looks at Ringo who is innocently occupied, a malicio into GRANDFATHER's eye. He decides to have a go at RINGO staring at him. RINGO gradually becomes aware of the star uncomfortably then tries to continue reading his book.
(disgustedly to no one in particular) Will you ever look at him, sitting there wid his hooter scraping away at that book!
Well ... what's the matter with that?
(taking the book from him) Have you no natural resources of your own? Have they even robbed you of that?
(snatching back his book) You can learn from books.
Can you now? Aah ... sheeps' heads! You learn more by getting out there and living.
Out where?
Any old where ... but not our little Richard ++. oh no! When you're not thumping them pagan skins, you're tormenting your eyes wid that rubbish!
(defiantly) Books are good!
(countering) Parading's better!
Parading?
(marching up and down the canteen) That's it, parading the streets ... trailing your coat ... bowling along ... living!
Well, I am living, aren't I?
You're living, are you? When was the last time you gave a girl a pink-edged daisy? When did you last embarrass a sheila wid your cool appraising stare?
Eh ... you're a bit old for that sort of chat, aren't you?
At least I've a backlog of memories, but all you've got is that book!
Aaah ... stop picking on me... you're as bad as the rest of them.
So you are a man after all.
What's that mean?

Do you think I haven't noticed ... do you think I wasn't aware of the drift? Oh ... you poor unfortunate scuff, they've driven you into books by their cruel, unnatural treatment, exploiting your good nature.
(not too sure) Oh ... I dunno.
(confidingly) And that lot's never happier than when they're jeering at you ... and where would they be without the steady support of your drum beat, I'd like to know.
Yeah ... that's right.
And what's it all come to in the end?
(defensively) Yeah ... what's in it for me?
A book!
Yeah ... a bloomin' book! He throws the book down.

When you could be out there betraying a rich American widow or sipping palm wine in Tahiti before you're too old like me. A fine neat and trim lad the class of you should be helping himself to life's goodies before the sands run out. Being an old age pensioner's a terrible drag on a man and every second you waste is bringing you nearer the Friday queue at the Post Office.
Yeah ... funny really, 'cos I'd never thought of it but being middle-aged and old takes up  most of your time, doesn't it?
(nodding) You're only right.
(nodding back) I'm not wrong. There is a pause, then RINGO rises and crosses to the doo
Where are you off to?

I'm going parading before it's too late! RINGO leaves and GRANDFATHER laughs at what he has done, its full meaning and looks worried. 59. INTERIOR CORRIDOR and STAIRWAY RINGO comes along the corridor then down the narrow stair down he comes face to face with GEORGE who is coming up t
Eh, Ringo, do you know what happened to me?
(passing him) No. I don't. As he goes round the corner RINGO turns on the surprised
You want to stop being so scornful, it's twisting your face.

head_text.subj: INTERIOR T.V. THEATRE NEAR STAGE DOORMAN'S OFFICE

text: JOHN and PAUL are chatting up a couple of girls, when the approaching they break off the conversation.
Here he is, the middle-aged boy wonder. RINGO looks at JOHN hard.
Eh. I thought you were looking after the old man.
(with simple dignity) Get knotted! PAUL and JOHN gape at him. For good measure Ringo takes photograph of them before he leaves them flabbergasted an into the street.
We've got only half an hour till the final run-through. He can't walk out on us.
Can't he? He's done it, son! GEORGE runs towards them.
Eh, I don't know if you realise it, but ...
We do.
Yes. Your grandfather's stirred him up.
He hasn't.
Yes, he's filled his head with notions seemingly.
The old mixer, come on we'll have to put him right. The three of them go into the street.

head_text.subj: EXTERIOR T.V. THEATRE STAGE DOOR ENTRANCE

text: The boys look up and down but RINGO has completely disapp
We'll split up and search for him, he can't be far. They now all start to go off in the same direction, they are three roads they can take but each time they begin to all go the same way.
It's happened at last, we've become a limited company.
I'll look in here again. PAUL gives him a push to the left and GEORGE to the right straight ahead himself they part and go their separate wa  62.

RINGO is walking along taking photographs with his camera girls recognise him and start to follow him. They quicken and RINGO runs ahead of them. He turns and comes into ano He sees a second-hand clothes shop with a sign saying "We Anything" moment the 63. to tyre and enters the shop just before the pursuing girls come r corner. The girls stand about looking in all directions. RINGO comes out of the shop. He is wearing a long mackint natty cap pulled well down. He is ignored by the girls wh recognise him. Realising this he goes back and ogles one glares at him.
Hello.
Get out of it, short house! CLOSE-UP on Ringo's secret but happy smile as he walks br road.

RINGO kicks at a brick. He kicks stylishly but misses so misses again, but finally kicks the stone which doesn't b bends down and pulls it out of the ground. It is quite bi quarters of it being below the surface. Having got it he throw it away. As he does so the same POLICEMAN rides pas bicycle.
Ain't you got no more bleeding sense than to go round chucking bricks about. Before RINGO has time to answer the man has disappeared.

(shouting after him) Southerner! He looks at the canal water moodily; at this moment a lar rolls down the incline and bashes him slap in the back, s on the path, the tyre on top of him. A small boy appears and stands over the prostrate RINGO.
Here, mate, that's my hoop, stop playing with it.
Hoop, this isn't a hoop, it's a lethal weapon. Have you got a licence for it?
Oh don't be so stroppy!
(getting up) Well! A boy of your age bowling "hoop" at people. How old are you anyway?
(aggressively) Nine.
Bet you're only eight and a half.
(countering swiftly) Eight and two thirds.
Well, there you are and watch it with that hoop.
Gerron out of it, you're only jealous ‘cause you're old.
Shurrup!
I bet you're (searching for an age) -- sixteen!
Fifteen and two thirds, actually.
Well --
All right, take your hoop and bowl. He moves off and the BOY follows.
Oh you can have it, I'm packing it in -- it depresses me.
Y'what?
You heard, it gets on my wick.
Well that's lovely talk, that is. And another thing, why aren't you at school?
I'm a deserter.
(smiling in spite of himself) Are you now?
Yeah, I've blown school out.
Just you?
No, Ginger, Eddy Fallon and Ding Dong.
Ding Dong? Oh Ding Dong Bell, eh?
Yeah, that's right, they was supposed to come with us but they chickened.
Yeah? And they're your mates are they?
(sighing) Yeah.
Not much cop without 'em, is it?
(defensively) Oh, it's all right.
(disbelievingly) Yeah?
Yeah.
What they like? BOY is glad to have something to talk about.
(enthusiastically)  Ginger's mad, he says things all the time and Eddy's good at punching and spitting.
How about Ding Dong?
He's a big head and he fancies himself with it but you know it's all right ‘cos he's one of the gang. RINGO nods his head understandingly and they mooch on tog
Why aren't you at work?
I'm a deserter, too.
Oh. At this moment a child's voice shouts out "Charley" and f P.O.V. we see three kids. RINGO turns to the BOY and look enquiringly.
(to Ringo) See you. The BOY runs off to join his mates. As he joins them they scuffle together. They are obviously a gang. RINGO is lef

GEORGE comes round the corner, looking for RINGO, then gr past a sign saying "Canteen and Production Office Opposit to the exit door, crosses to a modern building across fro theatre. He enters [the] building.
It is the reception room that leads to an inner office. B sits a smart young woman typing busily as GEORGE enters. surprised when he sees the girl; she looks up and speaks once.
Oh, there you are!
Oh, I'm sorry, I must have made a mistake.
(tartly) You haven't, you're just late.  66. (She rises and crossing over to him examines him critically.) Oh, yes, he's going to be very pleased with you.
Is he?

Yes, you're quite a feather in the cap. (She crosses to the desk and picks up the inter-office phone.) Hello, I've got one ... oh, I think so ... yes, he can talk ... Well ... I think you ought to see him. (she smiles) Of course, right away. She crosses to the inter-office door. On the door is writ MARSHAL ... she opens it.
Well ... come on.
Sorry. He follows her quickly in.

A large room, part production office with models and sets board with ground plans, the other part of the room a mix and Queen's magazine decor. Behind a large desk sits SIMON MARSHAL, a bland but sligh young man of about thirty-five. He is wearing the ultimat current smart set fashion. He is attended by a couple of ADRIAN and TONY and behind him on the wall is a poster of Across the poster is printed, "Way Out, your own T.V. Spe with Susan Campey. Director, Simon Marshal."
(proudly) Will this do, Simon?
(looking at George) Not bad, dolly, not really bad. (he motions to George) Turn around, chicky baby. GEORGE does so.

Oh yes, a definite poss. He'll look good alongside Susan. (he indicates the girl on the poster) All right, Sunny Jim, this is all going to be quite painless. Don't breathe on me, Adrian. ADRIAN has recognised GEORGE and is trying to stop SIMON.
Look, I'm terribly sorry but I'm afraid there's been some sort of a misunderstanding.
(sharply) Oh, you can come off it with us. You don't have to do the old adenoidal glottal stop and carry on for our benefit.
I'm afraid I don't understand.
Oh, my God, he's a natural. SECRETARY (anxiously) Well, I did tell them not to send us any more real ones.
They ought to know by now the phonies are much easier to handle. Still he's a good type. He now speaks to GEORGE in the loud voice that the Englis foreigners and village idiots.
We want you to give us your opinion on some clothes for teenagers.
Oh, by all means, I'd be quite prepared for that eventuality.
Well, not your real opinion, naturally. It'll be written out and you'll learn it. (to secretary) Can he read?
Of course I can.
I mean lines, ducky, can you handle lines?
I'll have a bash.
Good. Hart, get him whatever it is they drink, a cokearama?
Ta.
Well, at least he's polite. Tony Show him the shirts, Adrian. A collection of shirts are produced and GEORGE looks at t is doing this SIMON briefs him.
Now, you'll like these. You really "dig" them. They're "fab" and all the other pimply hyperboles.
I wouldn't be seen dead in them. They're dead grotty.
Grotty?
Yeah, grotesque.

(to secretary) Make a note of that word and give it to Susan. I think it's rather touching really. Here's this kid trying to give me his utterly valueless opinion when I know for a fact within four weeks he'll be suffering from a violent inferiority complex and loss of status if he isn't wearing one of these nasty things. Of course they're grotty, you wretched nit, that's why they were designed, but that's what you'll want.
But I won't.
You can be replaced you know, chicky baby.
I don't care.
And that pose is out too, Sunny Jim. The new thing is to care passionately, and be right wing. Anyway, you won't meet Susan if you don't cooperate.
And who's this Susan when she's at home?
(playing his ace) Only Susan Campey, our resident teenager. You'll have to love her. She's your symbol.
Oh, you mean that posh bird who gets everything wrong?
I beg your pardon?
Oh, yes, the lads frequently gather round the T.V. set to watch her for a giggle. Once we even all sat down and wrote these letters saying how gear she was and all that rubbish.
She's a trend setter. It's her profession!
She's a drag. A well-known drag. We turn the sound down on her and say rude things.
Get him out of here!!
(genuinely surprised) Have I said something amiss?
Get him out of here. He's knocking the programme's image!! The underlings hustle GEORGE to the door.
(smiling) Sorry about the shirts. He is ejected through the door.
Get him out. (he stops in mid-shout) You don't think he's a new phenomenon, do you?
You mean an early clue to the new direction?

(rummaging in his desk) Where's the calendar? (he finds it) No, he's just a trouble maker. The change isn't due for three weeks. All the same, make a note not to extend Susan's contract. Let's not take any unnecessary chances!

head_text.subj: EXTERIOR STREET PUB ON THE CORNER

text: The sign on the pub is Liverpool Arms. RINGO is standing it. He decides to go in and does so.
The atmosphere is tense. GRANDFATHER is standing miserabl the DIRECTOR, the criminal confronted by the judge. SHAKE flanking him grimly.
I'm sorry lads, I didn't mean it, honest.
If he says that again, I'll strike him.
(unconvincingly) They'll be back, they're good lads, they'll be back.
(disgusted) Yes? Well they've got only ten minutes to the final run-through.
I meant no harm. I was only trying to encourage little Ringo to enjoy himself.
(grimly, C.U.) God knows what you've unleashed on the unsuspecting South. It'll be wine, women and song all the way with Ringo once he's got the taste for it.
CLOSE-UP on RINGO. He is eating a bone dry sandwich that the end. He puts it down with disgust. He has a lager gla hand.

(accusingly) That was fresh this morning. We now see the pub is full of enormous cockney workmen do RINGO is very much alone. He moves away from the bar tow that is standing together, they've an average height of o There is a group at a dart board. Another group is playin skittles and a third group is around a pin-ball table. Near the bar is a shove-halfpenny board with two players. caged parrot nearby.

(to Ringo) That'll be two and nine... RINGO fumbles some change out of his pocket. A few copper his hand on to the shove-halfpenny board just as the cruc been made. The men glare at him. Embarrassed, he moves aw without looking, places his glass on the skittles table just as a swings the string, which hits Ringo's glass. More embarrassed, R away, unfortunately into the pin-table just as a winning about to be reached. He bumps it very slightly, but enough to c TILT. He then moves to the dart board. By this time most staring at him. With great style he takes the darts. The goes into a cheese sandwich which a man is pointing in de The second we see arrive into a pint of bitter and then w shoot the third dart and hear the sound of the parrot sho angrily, off. The BARMAID has had enough.
Right ... On your way!
Y'what?
You heard, on your way, troublemaker! Now the centre of attention, RINGO backs out of the pub, every eye in the place, the BARMAID and a few players fol the door
RINGO comes out and crosses road, watched by the POLICEMA quite suspicious.

PAUL comes down the street looking about him for RINGO. I is an old building, the sort of place that is highly favo rehearsals. There is a sign on the door, "TV Rehearsal Ro draws near, a load of actors and extras, etc. are leaving costume, they are the ones who earlier had been going to rehearsal. When PAUL gets near the entrance he decides to  72. 73.
PAUL enters and wanders about. He reaches a door, pushes looks in. He sees a GIRL clad in period costume. She is m the room and obviously acting. PAUL watches her for a mom decides to go in.

PAUL goes into the room. The GIRL is in mid-flight. She i and lovely and completely engrossed in what she is doing. absolutely empty except for PAUL and herself. She is acti manner of an eighteenth-century coquette, or, to be preci English actresses use when they think they are being true costume period ... her youth however makes it all very ch

If I believed you, sir, I might do those things and walk those ways only to find myself on Problem's Path. But I cannot believe you, and all those urgings serve only as a proof that you will lie and lie again to gain your purpose with me. She dances lightly away from an imaginary lover and as sh sees PAUL who is as engrossed in the scene as she was.
(surprised) oh!
(enthusiastically) Well ... go ‘head, do the next bit.
Go away! You've spoilt it.
Oh, sorry I spoke. He makes no attempt to go. He simply continues to look st girl; then he smiles at her. She is undecided what to do
Are you supposed to be here?
I've got you worried, haven't I?
I'm warning you, they'll be back in a minute.
D'you know something, "They" don't worry me at all. Anyroad, I only fancy listening to you  .».. that's all but if it worries you ... well ...
You're from Liverpool, aren't you?
(ironically) How'd you guess?
(seriously) Oh, it's the way you talk.
(innocently) Is it ... is it, really?
(suspiciously) Are you pulling my leg?
(looking her straight in the eye) Something like that.
(unsure) I see. (airily) Do you like the play?
Yeah ... I mean, sure, well, I took it at school but I only ever heard boys and masters saying those lines, like, sounds different on a girl. (smiles to himself) Yeah, it's gear on a girl.
Gear?
Aye, the big hammer, smashing!
Thank you.
Don't mench ... well, why don't you give us a few more lines, like? GIRL pouts.
You don't half slam the door in people's faces,  do you? I mean, what about when you're playing the part, like, hundreds of people'll see you and...
(cutting in) I'm not ...
Oh, you're the understudy, sort of thing?
No. (aggressively) I'm a walk-on in a fancy dress scene. I just felt like doing those lines.
Oh, I see. You are an actress though, aren't you?
Yes.
Aye, I knew you were.
What's that mean?
Well, the way you were spouting, like .... (he imitates her) "I don't believe you, sir..." and all that. Yeah, it was gear.
(dryly) The big hammer?
(smiling) Oh aye, a sledge.
But the way you did it then sounded so phony.
No ... I wouldn't say that ... just like an actress ... you know. He moves and stands about like an actress.
But that's not like a real person at all.
Aye well, actresses aren't like real people, are they?
They ought to be.
Oh, I don't know, anyroad up, they never are, are they?
(teasingly) What are you?
I'm in a group ... well ... there are four of us, we play and sing.
I bet you don't sound like real people.
We do, you know. We sound like us having a ball. It's fab.
Is it really fab or are you just saying that to convince yourself?
What of? Look, I wouldn't do it unless I was. I'm dead lucky 'cos I get paid for doing something I love doing. He laughs and with a gesture takes in the whole studio
-+. all this and a jam butty too!!
I only enjoy acting for myself. I hate it when other people are let in.
Why? I mean, which are you, scared or selfish?
Why selfish?
Well, you've got to have people to taste your treacle toffee. She looks at him in surprise.

No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You see, when  I was little me mother let me make some treacle toffee one time in our back scullery. When I'd done she said to me, "Go and give some to the other kids." So, I said I would but I thought to meself, "She must think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating away there but I wanted somebody else to know how good it was so in the end I wound up giving it all away ... but I didn't mind, mind, ‘cos I'd made the stuff in the first place. Well ... that's why you need other people... an audience ... to taste your treacle toffee, like. Eh ... does that sound as thickheaded to you as it does to me?
Not really but I'm probably not a toffee maker. How would you do those lines of mine?
Well, look at it this way, I mean, when you come right down to it, that girl, she's a bit of a scrubber, isn't she?
Is she?

Of course ... Look, if she was a Liverpool scrubber ... (Paul starts acting a Liverpool girl, he minces about then turns, extending his leg) Eh, fella, you want to try pulling the other one, it's got a full set of bells hanging off it... Y'what? ... I know your sort, two cokes and a packet of cheese and onion crisps and suddenly it's love and we're stopping in an empty shop doorway. You're just after me body and y'can't have it ... so there!!
(shattered) And you honestly think that's what she meant?

Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile, she's trying to get him to marry her but he doesn't want ... well ... I don't reckon any fella's ever wanted to get married. But girls are like that, clever and cunning. You've got to laugh. He laughs.
Well, it's nice to know you think we're clever.
(grinning) And cunning.
And what do you do about it?
Me? Oh, I don't have the time, I'm always running about with the lads ... no, we don't have the time.
Pity.
(not noticing the invitation) Aye, it is but as long as you get by, it's all right, you know ... bash on, happy valley's when they let you stop. Anyroad, I'd better get back.
Yes.
(going) See you.
Of course. PAUL stands at the doorway, shrugs then goes out.

In the street, workmen are collecting shovels, drinking t all the things people do around building sites. RINGO moo In the road is a hole with a diameter of about 3 feet, an feet deep. RINGO looks down and a man is busily working a of the hole. He glares at RINGO. After a moment RINGO tur now see a very elegant young lady coming towards RINGO. S daintily avoiding a series of puddles. RINGO has an idea and does Raleigh with his large Mac spreading it over one of the p girl walks across it smiling graciously. RINGO proceeds w to the next puddle and to the next backing gradually towa At last he spreads the coat, without noticing what he is the hole. The girl steps onto the coat and disappears sha looks down the hole where the girl is held in the workman workman rises out of the manhole until he is waist height point an elegantly dressed gentleman appears (the girl's looks at his wife in the workman's arms and hits the work backs away through the puddles, and is nicked by the POLI [Scenes 75 and 76 deleted in revision. ]  77.

head_text.subj: INTERIOR T.V. THEATRE NEAR STAGE DOOR

text: The DIRECTOR is pacing up and down the corridor. NORM is up and down, SHAKE is leaning against the wall quite unco gives SHAKE a push.
Worry, will you! SHAKE adjusts his features to a worrying expression.
(bitterly) Well, that's it, two minutes to the final run-through... they're bound to miss it...
I'll murder that Lennon.
But I suppose we can survive a missed run-through as long...
... as they head up for the show. Oh yes, well I mean it'ud be a pity to miss the show, wouldn't it like.
Shurrup, cheerful. The horrible prospect hits the DIRECTOR.
You don't think...
(reassuring him) They'll be here.
Oh now, they can't do that to me. (turning on Norm) It's all your fault. (overriding Norm) Oh yes it is and if they don't turn up I wouldn't be in your shoes for all the...
(helping out) ... tea in China. Oh you're right, neither would I. He steps away from NORM and stands near the DIRECTOR.
Traitor! SHAKE nods his agreement to this assessment of his chara
Of course. At this moment JOHN, GEORGE and PAUL enter from the stage are completely unconcerned and walk past the DIRECTOR, SH
(as he passes by) Hi Norm!
(preoccupied) Hi, our lot! The BOYS walk on when after a moment NORM snaps to.
Our lot!
(mildly) Did you want something.
(beaming with delight) I could eat the lot of you.
You'd look gear with an apple in your gob.
(accusingly) Do you realise you could have missed the final run-through?
Sorry.
Eh, there's only three of them.
Aye, we were looking for Ringo. But we realised he must have come back.
Do you realise we are on the air, live, in front of an audience, in forty-five minutes and you're one short.
Control yourself or you'll spurt. He's bound to be somewhere.  78. who hop 79.
Aye, let's try the dressing room. Everyone starts along the passage. NORM and PAUL last.
Eh, where's my grandfather?
Don't worry about him. He can look after himself.
Aye, I suppose so. They run after the others.

Here they are, personally signed and handwritten by your own sweet boys. The chance of a lifetime. Be the envy of your less fortunate sisters! The CAMERA PULLS back and we see GRANDFATHER is surrounde have broken from the queue and are doing a brisk trade wi man. He has a large sign on which is written: "Get your g autographed Beatles photographs." On the edge of the crow POLICEMEN are trying to force the girls back into the que they wade through the girls and confront GRANDFATHER. The old man quizzically; he stares back coldly. They indicate it and quick but GRANDFATHER defiantly glares back at the sigh, they grab an arm each and escort the old man off.
It is the reception desk and behind it is the DESK SERGEA moment RINGO is dragged in by the POLICEMAN we saw him wi
Look, I'm Ringo Starr... I've got a show to do in a few minutes you've got to let me go... I'm Ringo...
Sure, they all say that these days ... Anyway ++. I don't care who you are... you can save that for the stipendary. Here you are, Sarge.
What is he?
(reeling off the list)  I've got a little list here. Wandering abroad. Malicious intent. Acting in a suspicious manner. Conduct liable to cause a breach of the peace. You name it, he's done it.
Oh, a little savage, is he?
A proper Aborigine.
(on his dignity) I demand to see me solicitor.
What's his name?
Oh, well if you're going to get technical -- At that moment there is a loud series of noises off camer shouting and dull crashes of wood.

Hello, it's going to be one of those nights, is it? (to policeman) sit Charley Peace down over there. The POLICEMAN takes RINGO to a bench and sits him down as and the two POLICEMEN who were with him enter. The sign i and is being lugged after them.

Well, you got me here so do your worst but I'll take one of you with me. (kicks the nearest policeman) Oh, I know your game, get me in the tiled room and out come the rubber hoses but I'll defy you still.
Is there a fire, then? GRANDFATHER leans across the desk and hisses at the SERGE
You ugly, great brute you, you have sadism stamped all over your bloated British kisser.
Eh?
I'll go on a hunger strike. I know your caper. The kidney punch and the rabbit-clout. The  third degree and the size twelve boot ankle-tap.
What's he on about?
(squaring up) I'm soldier of the Republic, you'll need the mahogany truncheon for this boyo. A nation once again.

(to policemen) Get Lloyd George over there with that mechanic in the cloth cap while I sort this lot out. The POLICEMEN hurtle GRANDFATHER firmly but gently over t which RINGO is sitting and then return to the desk for a conference with the SERGEANT. Meanwhile in full conspirat GRANDFATHER talks to RINGO out of the side of his mouth.
Ringo, me old scout, they grabbed yer leg for the iron too, did they?
Well I'm not exactly a voluntary patient.
Shush! Have they roughed you up yet?
What?
(whispering) Keep your voice down, this lot'll paste you, just for the exercise. Oh they're a desperate crew of drippings and they've fists like matured hams for pounding defenceless lads like you.
(disturbed) Have they?
That sergeant's a body-blow veteran if ever I measured one. One of us has got to escape. I'll get the boys. Hold on son, I'll be back for you.
(horrified) Me !
And if they get you on the floor watch out for your brisket.
(hopefully) Oh, they seem all right to me.
That's what they want you to think. All coppers are villains.
(calling) Would you two like a cup of tea?
You see, sly villains.
(miserable) No thanks, Mr. Sergeant, sir. We now have a CLOSE SHOT of POLICEMEN around the sergeant
So you just brought the old chap out of the crowd for his own good.
Yeah, but he insisted on us bringing him to the station.
Well, he can't stop here. Shot of GRANDFATHER watching POLICEMEN intently and mutte he does.
What are you doing?
Lip reading.
What are they saying?
Nothing good. The POLICEMEN make a move towards GRANDFATHER and RINGO.
Well son, it's now or never. He jumps to his feet and scurries towards the door.
All right, you paid assassins. Johnny McCartney'll give you a run for your threepence ha'penny. He dashes out of the door followed by the POLICEMAN who h of photos.
Now, what's he up to?
He's allergic to Bobbies, especially English Bobbies. The POLICEMAN with the photos returns.
(Irish accent) Your man disappeared like a leveret over a hill.
Turncoat! The POLICEMEN turn on RINGO and walk towards him.
Mother!

GRANDFATHER is running at top speed down the street. He i heavily and runs as if pursued by the hounds of hell. The however is entirely empty and no one is even in sight. As the top of the street he pauses and turning, looks around his P.O.V. we see just how empty the street is and heaving a relief GRANDFATHER cackles to himself. His triumph is short live precise moment down the street comes a parade of police v Black Maria, an escorting police motor bike patrol and an squad car. The procession draws up and the street is full getting out of the Black Maria and squad car and off moto CLOSE-UP GRANDFATHER's horrified face.

Be God, they've called up reinforcements, the dragnet's out! He dashes off wildly in the general direction of the thea been completely unnoticed by the policemen who are lining last minute inspection by the inspector in charge. The inspec commander-in-chief of a spear-head attack force. They smartly march off in the direction taken by GRANDFAT 81. INTERIOR T.
(watching the clock) Only half an hour and you're on!
Can I say something? The director clutches at any straw.
(hopefully) Yes, anything.
(earnestly) It's highly unlikely we'll be on... I mean the law of averages are against you and it seems that, etc., etc.... But his speech is drowned by the pitiful moans of the DIR
The four little boys from the canal are being driven away security guard.

(going back into theatre) I'll have the hides off of you lot. The kids retreat as GRANDFATHER pants into shot, ignoring enters the stage door but in a second he is out again, gr by the collar by the security guard.
You ought to be ashamed of yourself. Go home!
I must see Pauly.
Go home then and see him on the telly. The GUARD re-enters the stage door. GRANDFATHER looks around him and sees the four kids. He h and after a whispered conference we hear his offer.
Can you fix him for me?
Yeah.
Sixpence.
Each? GRANDFATHER is about to argue.
Oh, all right.
And in advance.
(disgusted) Mercenary! But he hands over the money. The kids rush in the stage d a moment the furious GUARD chases them out and down the a GRANDFATHER, chuckling, nips in the door.

head_text.subj: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM ON STAGE

text: GRANDFATHER is being chased by several studio attendants; dodging behind equipment. He finally gets on a sound boom trolley as a weapon to keep his pursuers at bay.
The DIRECTOR, BOYS, and NORM and SHAKE see GRANDFATHER on monitors. They dash out of the room and on to the stage.
(shouting) It's all right, leave him alone.
Grandad, where's Ringo?
The police have the poor unfortunate lad in the Bridewell.
The police station.
He'll be pulp by now.
station coppers 86. 87. What are we waiting for?
Come here. PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE rush off.
We've only got twenty minutes.

PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE come running down the street in sin their knees high in the air, they skid to a halt at the p and without pausing they dash inside. After a moment they only this time RINGO is behind them. They dash off down t They are followed at once by ten POLICEMEN also in single are also pounding along knees high in the air. The BOYS a disappear around the corner. At once, they reappear from direction, then run down the street still followed by the When they reach the police station another group of polic way so they are forced to run up the stairs and inside.

The DESK SERGEANT is standing behind his desk looking ver At this moment the boys run in and stand panting in front Before the SERGEANT can start speaking the pursuing POLIC They, too, are out of breath.
What is all this?
(heaving and panting) Hold on until we get our breath. The BOYS and POLICEMEN pant on until JOHN seems to have r
All right now?
Sure. (to boys) Ready? The BOYS nod and without further ado they turn and run th surprised rank of POLICEMEN and out into the street.

Shots of BOYS being pursued (still in single file) by po including the sergeant with one shot where the BOYS are chasing the Finally, as they approach the theatre, they are seen by t who swarm around the police, over running them. The boys other and are about to make off when from their P.O.V. we INSPECTOR and POLICEMEN blocking it.
Ah well, it was worth a try.
(calling to Sergeant) What do you think you're up to?
Arrest those boys, sir.

That's all we need to start a real riot! (to Boys) Come on lads, they're waiting for you. Het INTERIOR THEATRE BACKSTAGE The Inspector now hustles the BOYS through the crowds and the main entrance of the theatre where SHAKE and NORM are

looks suspiciously at RINGO who is still wearing his cap. it off and NORM delightedly hugs him. The BOYS dash throu entrance and on stage. The DIRECTOR sees them and bursts with relief. NORM hustles the lads into the wings to be c their show costumes. All around them last-minute preparat going on.
Boys, you don't know what this means to me. If you hadn't come back it would have been the epilogue or the news in Welsh for life.
Aren't you supposed to be in that box? The DIRECTOR gives NORM a final glare and dashes off.
And another thing, where's that old mixer?
Here, Pauly. And sitting on a box sadly chastened sits GRANDFATHER.
Well, I got a few things to say to you, two-faced John McCartney.  old 88. of
Aw, leave him alone Paul, he's back, isn't he? And it's not his fault he's old.
(hotly) What's old got to do with it?
You needn't bother.
Y'what?
Practising to be thick-headed, you're there already.
Look he's a mixer and a trouble maker!
That's right, but he's only asking us to pay attention to him, aren't you? From JOHN's P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER. He looks what he i man.

You see. (to Grandad) You know your trouble -- you should have gone West to America. You'd have wound up a Senior Citizen of Boston. As it is you took the wrong turning and what happened, you're a lonely old man from Liverpool.
(fighting back) But I'm clean. The BOYS giggle and slap him on the back.

We see the audience of girls streaming in and settling do places for the show. There is the usual business of getti ready and we see SHOTS of the girls' faces, then JOHN, PA GEORGE looking at them. At last on cue from the floor man start their act to the audience's screams. During the num constantly CUT away to the audience with various SHOTS of girls. In the middle of these shots we see NORM standing  and spite medley of finish 89. the audience his face glowing with satisfaction. We follo from NORM'S P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER handcuffed to SHAKE of this, the old man is enjoying himself. The BOYS now pe of numbers, i.e., a little of all the songs we have heard story. This gives the impression of a full set and we fin their bows. While they are doing so they look again in th direction of SHAKE and GRANDFATHER and from their P.O.V., is beating time to the music but from his wrist dangles a handcuffs. GRANDFATHER has gone again. As the BOYS are re GRANDFATHER's disappearance once again, the trap door on opens and GRANDFATHER appears in the centre of the group their act and take their final bows.
NORM is waiting for the boys. With him are two studio att carrying the boys' luggage. As the BOYS excitedly appear them.
I've got the stuff. Come here.
Aren't we ...
No, we're not! He hurries them along.
The office was on the phone, they think it'd be better if we pushed straight to Wolverhampton.
Tonight? We can't make it ...
You've got a midnight matinee.
Now, look here, Norm...
No, you look here, John. I've only one thing to say to you.
What?
You're a swine. So hurry up ... we're  travelling! NORM turns down a side exit where the door is open to the is an eight-passenger helicopter.
The BOYS and NORM come out of the building and start to r the helicopter.
(looking behind him) Where's my grandfather?
(arriving at helicopter door) Don't start. Look. The boys look in the passenger bay and there is GRANDFATH still handcuffed to SHAKE but clutching his pile of photo
(beckoning them in with his free hand which holds the photos) Come on, you're hanging up the parade. The boys shout “Get rid of those things, etc."

The final shot is of the helicopter rising up (SHOT FROM disappears, a shower of photos come from its window. We cut to a CLOSE-UP of one signed photo as it hits the g SUPER the closing credits over it. Screenplay by Alun Owen
